greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of cubic nonresidues modulo n.
comment: a(n) is the number of values r, 0<=r<n, such that, for p=3 and for any m>=0, (m^p)%n != r. Compared to quadratic nonresidues (p=2, sequence A095972), the most evident difference is the frequent occurrence of a(n)=0 (for values of n which belong to A074243).
link: Stanislav Sykora, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: Satisfies a(n) <= n-3 (residues 0, 1, and n-1 are always present).
example: a(5)=0, because the set {(k^3)%5}, with k=0..4, evaluates to {0,1,3,2,4},
a(7)=4, because the set {(k^3)%7}, with k=0..6, evaluates to
maple: seq(n - nops({seq(a^3 mod n,a=0..n-1)}), n=1..100); # _Robert Israel_, Apr 20 2015
program: a(n)=my(f=factor(n)); n-prod(i=1, #f~, g(f[i,1], f[i,2])) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Apr 20 2015
xref: Nonresidues for other exponents: A095972 (p=2), A257302 (p=4), A257303 (p=5).
results.author: _Stanislav Sykora_, Apr 19 2015
